docs.lead_paragraph: It was in my second year of medical school that I learned one of the most important lessons of my career: That it can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer. Certainty was what I craved the most back then, poised as I was on the threshold of my medical career. But my first patient would cure me of certainty forever.

headline.main: A Life Lesson Learned in Medical School

docs.abstract: A patient who produces a surprising response to a time-tested question teaches a valuable lesson: It can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer.
docs.snippet: A patient who produces a surprising response to a time-tested question teaches a valuable lesson: It can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Friday Reading: More Internet Calling Options

docs.abstract: More free Internet calling options, a fierce defense of the banks and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.
docs.snippet: More free Internet calling options, a fierce defense of the banks and other consumer-focused items from Friday's Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fabiola Santiago lives in the Miami suburbs, two miles from her 81-year-old mother and 87-year-old father, whom she looks after. As the single mother of three grown daughters, she might live in the city or in Miami Beach if she had no family responsibilities -- but to her, that's like saying she'd fly if she woke up tomorrow with wings. It's a fantasy.
docs.abstract: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.
docs.snippet: Caregiving obligations are deeply felt in many Hispanic families, but tradition is running up against harsh modern realities, experts say.

docs.lead_paragraph: Japan’s economy is clogged with aging vested interests, frustrating the young people needed to maintain its edge.

headline.seo: Japan Blocks the Young, Stifling the Economy

headline.print_headline: Japan Blocks the Young, Stifling the Economy

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the major concerns about the new health care law is whether it will usher in the demise of employer-based coverage, which is the source of insurance for the bulk of working Americans today.
docs.abstract: A new study suggests that employer-based coverage will survive.
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that employer-based coverage will survive.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care experts tout accountable care organizations as the system’s best hope for the future, but engaging patients is crucial to their success.

docs.lead_paragraph: Keeping a pet healthy can be expensive. But is it worth buying insurance to cover those  expenses?
docs.abstract: An argument for self-insuring your pet, rather than buying pet insurance.
docs.snippet: An argument for self-insuring your pet, rather than buying pet insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, the military has been encouraging its active duty troops to acknowledge the emotional and psychological stress of deployment, hoping to break through the resistance some people have to seeking help.

headline.main: Veterans, Like Active Duty Troops, Are Hesitant to Seek Mental Health Care

docs.abstract: Many veterans said they feared that seeking treatment would lead colleagues or bosses to lose respect for them and would hurt their careers.
docs.snippet: Many veterans said they feared that seeking treatment would lead colleagues or bosses to lose respect for them and would hurt their careers.
